info.game_comments:
2012 Teen Tournament semifinal game 1.
From DAR Constitution Hall in Washington, D.C.

jeopardy_round: THEY NAMED A SCHOOL FOR ME

(1, 1).clue: A high school in north Hollywood, California is named for this aviator who lived nearby before she disappeared

(2, 1).clue: The first paragraph of this Dickens work says, "Old Marley was dead as a door-nail"

(3, 1).clue: At Knott's Berry Farm, there's an area full of rides just for kids called Camp this, after Charlie Brown's beagle

(4, 1).clue: When a government fixes prices at a set level, it's called one of these--b-r-r-r!

(5, 1).clue: James McAvoy said his movie kiss with this mother of Brad Pitt's children was awkward & sweaty

(1, 2).clue: Naval ROTC is a key part of the curriculum at the Florida academy named for this Civil War Admiral

(2, 2).clue: Liesel Meminger steals "The Gravedigger's Handbook" & other tomes in this WWII-set novel narrated by Death

(3, 2).clue: A British theme park inspired by this book includes a curvy caterpillars ride & queen of hearts crazy croquet

(4, 2).clue: Abbreviated CPI, it's a measure of the fluctuation of the cost of retail goods over a fixed time period

(5, 2).clue: Keira Knightley said Johnny Depp was a better smoocher than this other Caribbean pirate

(6, 2).clue: Type of "word" so common, it's familiar in everyone's home

(1, 3).clue: In 1693, this couple founded a college in Virginia

(2, 3).clue: Jean Louise Finch is the real name of the girl with this nickname in "To Kill a Mockingbird"

(3, 3).clue: The Smoky Mountain River Rampage is featured at this theme park named for country singer Parton

(4, 3).clue: It can be a record of what someone said or the current cost of a security or a stock

(5, 3).clue: This actress told Robert Downey Jr. he didn't know what he was doing when their lips met in "Iron Man 2"

(6, 3).clue: Something kept on from a previous administration

(1, 4).clue: A college of criminal justice in New York is named for this first Chief Justice

(2, 4).clue: This H.G. Wells story says the title figure has "goggling spectacles and (a) ghastly bandaged face"

(3, 4).clue: Appropriately, Holiday World is in the Indiana town named for this jolly guy

(4, 4).clue: Avian term for a reserve fund of money for retirement or emergencies

(5, 4).clue: Alyson Hannigan refused to kiss Jason Segel on this CBS sitcom due to his cigarette habit

(6, 4).clue: The point at which a stimulus, such as pain, has an effect

(1, 5).clue: This college, Amherst's rival, was named for a colonel killed in the French & Indian War

(2, 5).clue: 12-year-old Jonas is the receiver of memories in this novel by Lois Lowry

(3, 5).clue: Soak City is part of this Ohio amusement venue--get the point?

(4, 5).clue: In this market condition with the same last 5 letters as "Monopoly", there's more than one supplier firm, maybe just 3 or 4

(5, 5).clue: Thandie Newton griped that this "Mission: Impossible" star's kisses were "icky & sort of wet"

(1, 1).clue: In 2010 Nick Jonas took to the stage in London in this musical that features Jean Valjean

(2, 1).clue: She was still a teen when she became queen of Egypt in 51 B.C.

(3, 1).clue: This beloved sandwich cookie celebrated its 100th birthday on March 6, 2012

(4, 1).clue: The bacterium that causes bubonic plague was once named for this French scientist

(5, 1).clue: Ports on this gulf include Tampa & Tampico

(6, 1).clue: In high school "Weird Al" Yankovic was this highest-ranking member of the class academically

(1, 2).clue: It wasn't for "Spring Break" but for "Spring" this that Lea Michele was nominated for a Drama Desk Award in 2007

(2, 2).clue: Originally featuring only 1 sport--a foot race--the Olympics added this 5-event competition in 708 B.C.

(3, 2).clue: You might stay "Up All Night" listening to this boy band heard here

(4, 2).clue: Christmas disease is a type of this hereditary disease in which the blood doesn't clot normally

(5, 2).clue: Jamaica & Grenada are part of this island chain that got its name because Columbus didn't know where he was

(6, 2).clue: This word that means "to prove the truth of" comes from the Latin for "true"

(1, 3).clue: As seen and heard here, this show has been making a lot of noise off Broadway since 1994

(2, 3).clue: It's believed this rock group was built in England in three phases over 1,500 years, beginning around 3100 B.C.

(3, 3).clue: This 3-letter word comes before "Australia" in the name of a brand of sheepskin boots introduced to the U.S. by Brian Smith

(4, 3).clue: Celiac disease sufferers need to avoid bread or find some that's made without this protein

(5, 3).clue: Canada has a sort of equivalent song to "This Land Is Your Land"; its chorus begins, "From" this British Columbia island

(6, 3).clue: In poetry the legs of "Ozymandias" are this 4-letter synonym for big, "and trunkless"

(1, 4).clue: The title of this Tennessee Williams drama refers to Laura Wingfield's collection of animal figurines

(2, 4).clue: Shortly before drinking poison hemlock, this philosopher discussed with friends the fate of the human soul

(3, 4).clue: The Snow White story was retold in this 2012 movie with Julia Roberts as the evil queen

(4, 4).clue: Kidney failure means you need a transplant or to undergo this treatment that does a kidney's job

(5, 4).clue: (Here's Kelly) Punta Gallinas, South America's northernmost point, lies on the Guajira Peninsula, which is shared by these two nations

(1, 5).clue: This long-running musical is based on a 1911 horror novel by Gaston Leroux

(2, 5).clue: A popular TV & movie subject, this gladiator led a slave revolt that ended with his death in battle in 71 B.C.

(3, 5).clue: In 2012 an 81-year-old woman hit the jackpot, winning $336 million in the multi-state lottery with this 9-letter name

(4, 5).clue: The MCV4 vaccine protects against this childhood disease of the brain membranes

(5, 5).clue: Lake Itasca, considered the main source of the Mississippi River, is in this state

(6, 5).clue: This facial feature is named for Flemish painter Anthony

(0, 0).clue: Of the 5 elements with 4-letter names, it's the only one that is not a solid at room temperature
